description:
Olympic Flame Cafe is one of those places that makes your "gay gene" twitch.  While you're waiting for your food you're thinking how the beige vinyl booths could be in a more appealing color (really now, beige?);  how the collection of mismatched white boards could be replaced by one large black board with some deft chalk drawings in the margins.  There is SO much you could do to improve the decor (which is more than dated) then again it's also clean, unlike Moulin Rouge down the street, which is why we came here in the first place.

So, the food.   It's okay, I mean it's breakfast.  Some places can make breakfast into vacation food, or, like the Claremont Hotel, into bland spa food for dainty dieting socialites.  Here it's just breakfast.  I had a cheese burger which was a good basic burger, but nothing close to the one at Belcampo.  I had country potatoes with it, which were nicely seasoned and well cooked so that the potatoes had a good mix of hot/soft/crispy with some pan crisp thrown in for extra crunch.  My friend had the Western omelette with sour dough for toast and found it quite delicious without remark.  The portions were decent, and for the two of us, with coffee, the bill came to $27. which to me, for breakfast, is more than I want to pay (being that I could make all of it at home).

So, if breakfast home wasn't an option, this is a place I'd head to instead of Moulin Rouge.  What turns me off and will keep me out more than anything else though is the fact it's cash only.  Had I known this in advance, I wouldn't be writing this review as after 24 years of walking past the place, I would have kept walking.
author: Paul T.

description:
Not bad, but also not great. With so many other brunch options surrounding the Tenderloin, this shouldn't be your first option, but if you don't feel like waiting in line somewhere else nearby, this is a solid choice. 
 
I can only speak to the 3-egg omelets. The ingredients are some what basic, stuff you could buy at Safeway if you decide to cook your own omelet. The preparation is a-ok, the artichoke in the omelet was actually quite soft and well-cooked. 

If you're looking for a brunch place with no wait and low price, check em out.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Cash only, down and dirty breakfast joint. Large portions of food, one dollar cans of soda, and decent counter service. 

I'd leave this place to the locals.
author: Guy S.

description:
Wonderful place to eat!! Cash only! 
We had breakfast which was a lot of food for the price. Service was awesome!!! 
Bacon and pancakes were the bomb!!!
author: GiGi V.

description: Sad experience here. Tried to go in to buy a meal to give to a homeless man outside and was kicked out because they didn't want this man to be fed because they said "he's a thief".
author: Emily A.

description: I'm giving them 5 stars not because the food was great but Because this is exactly what I was looking for. Just breakfast. Bacon and eggs and hashbrowns and toast. With a place to sit. Lots of coffee. Believe it or not there are not a lot of places to sit in San Francisco so just being able to have indoor seating in this cold weather was great. The food came out quick and you could see the cookcook everything. The food was not bad and this is definitely a greasy spoon place. It would be nice if they could keep it a little cleaner but this is a true diner that looks like it's been around forever. If you're in the area and want quick cheap breakfast and plenty of coffee with indoor seating, this is the place.
author: Nate B.

description: Best spot for breakfast in the tenderloin! It is cash only, just so you are aware. Service is quick and the food is delicious. It's also very reasonably priced, especially for the portion sizes. It's a no frills great spot!
author: William Z.

description: Greasy spoon type of place. Been here forever. Not good decor or booths. Food was fine and there was quite a variety. It was entertaining with one waitress and the old cook doing all the work. The other waitress just leaned on the bar or sat. The busboy did very little also. This is a good SF experience
author: C W.

description:
This place was ok. Very good amount of food. But, unfortunately, their are some things that need improvement: 1) Service: when you enter, they just say pick a table for 2 not the tables that are for more people. We waited about 7 mins before getting service. Then waited another 4-5 kins before getting our coffee. 
2) Coffee was horrible. That's all I can say about that.
3) The place needs improvement: A little dirty. New tables; chairs; counters.. etc.. One positive thing we found was that the amount of food was a good portion...
author: Elliot C.

description: Read the reviews, thought it would be a decent hole in the wall diner breakfast joint. Nope, I was wrong. I walked in, no sign that says seat yourself or wait to be seated. Finally just sat in a clean booth. Waited 10 mins before the waitress came over and asked me if I was thirsty. Ummm, yeah, sure.... Ordered coffee & water. Coffee tasted like it had brewed over a week ago and was just kept on the warmer. As I wait for my Denver omelet I noticed that there were at least 7 other tables around me that all had dirty dishes on them and no one was cleaning them. It was gross. I finally get my omelet, it was certainly ok but nothing crazy good. I mean maybe if you're hungover, don't care what your food tastes like, and will basically eat anything then yeah, give it a shot! The booths are torn up and old, well actually the whole place is old and torn up. Oh, I almost forgot, they don't tell you they are cash only until you go to check out. I won't be back.
author: Thomas M.

description: This place is great. If you're looking for amazing diner food without the city prices, this is your place. For the past 7 months this has been my go to breakfast place. The waitresses are always nice and I've never had a problem with having to wait very long for anything. Good coffee, good chicken fried steak, eggs, corned beef hash, etc. I think the people that write terrible reviews about this place are just snooty snobs expecting some kind of 5 star gourmet experience, so if you're okay with something that isn't fancy, don't be scared away. You can get a full meal and some coffee for the price of something basic at Mel's, The Pinecrest, or Lori's, so it's worth trying.
author: Seichi M.

description: Breakfast is really good ,clean cozy place ....they serve breakfast only ,pancakes were delish!!!
author: Jesus G.

description: A nice place for breakfast. The furnitures are outdated but the food is excellent. The menu is exhaustive and the food is prepared to order.
author: Christian L.

description:
It's a great greasy spoon diner. 
Food is just what one would hope for. 
Reliable. Authentic. Fairly priced.
author: James H.

description:
Really good food,  nice servers, but one of the girls(russian) was really rude to everyone... not even a smile..yelling everyone ... and when I talk with her friend about her attitud they start laughing...really rude 
I don't want to go back.
author: Andrea R.

description: This is a very simple diner with great food, but service could improve . My friend loved his chocolate chip pancakes. I had a western omelette and asked for avocado, but didn't get it. I also asked for a side of veggies- our server asked me what kind, and I said zucchini, squash, onion, broccoli- which were on the menu on other dishes. I received a $5 plate of mushrooms and spinach. I just wish she'd have let me know that's what it would be. But my omelette was tasty and I would return to try other things. Just be sure that what you want is clearly communicated!
author: Kara V.

description: Service is run by exactly one busser, one server, and one chef. Food passable, server friendly, but don't come here if you are in the least hurry.
author: Zbv Z.

description:
Awesome!
What a greasy spoon should be unless you order it.(Bacon, Sausage) Service implacable. Prices $$.
25 years looking for a cook who knows how to make hash browns that aren't soggy.
author: Andrew A.

description: Well well well this should be interesting....this little refuge that works here named Julia is quite the interesting character...She has more prejudice than Donald Trump.... literally...she may as well have said this is a white only restaurant.... when I sat at the counter she immediately showed distaste...she not can't affect my food because I am sitting like a hawk watching the cook however she has not so nicely advised me that they were very busy (out of twenty tables only 5 were occupied and three people are sitting at the counter, I would hate to see how she responds when its extra busy)... They are above and beyond in rudeness and open prejudice... I may not eat the food but I am getting a kick outta making her uncomfortable as hell...she took my order however deliberately buried it behind orders that came after mine... why am I enduring this u ask... because they are the only ones open and my stomach "was" hungry ...at this point I really just wanna see how far with the rudeness will she go before I start call every agency I can to assist with there discomfort....
author: Leona Brat S.

description:
The food is good!
The decor is lacking.
Service is good.

Will definitely eat here again.
author: Stocky G.

description:
Yes, a "classic greasy spoon" - but great food without the grease.  

Breakfast here (no waiting) on New Year's morning was superb and cheap - $20.30 for two people for more than we could eat: Italian sausage, home fries, oatmeal, English muffins. I asked for lots of peanut butter and received enough to choke a horse (heaven).  Coffee well above average.  

The owner is a 75 y.o. amiable gent from southern Greece with lots of stories.  Decor is mid-50s and not, um, recently renewed, but so what?  I'm going back for more...
author: Matt B.

description: I am always looking for a breakfast place in San Francisco that does not have a line out the door. I walked past the Olympic Flame a few times before going in but am so happy I did. The place is funky from the outside but walking in smells like going back in time. The staff is friendly, the food is delicious and the price is extremely affordable. This will be my new favorite place to get pancakes and a good cup of coffee.
author: Susan R.

description: Loved it!  2 person operation of a grill cook and the waitress (who was fantastic) the morning I went. The Eggs Benedict was amazing. The decor was spartan and bland...maybe a bit worn or dated by most standards. If you're a fancy-pants lad/lass that needs to experience a certain type of ambiance whilst stuffing your pie hole, you may want to brunch down the street somewhere.  But if you're of the no-frills variety and looking for a greasy spoon with reasonable prices and good comfort food, this is your spot.
author: Ndiezel X.

description: This reminds me of the Greek coffee shops in Manhattan, in a way. The menu has lots of things to choose from...breakfast, lunch, and, dinner...breakfast all day. They have a counter that seats about 12 and a large dining room with big comfortable booths. Just enough funk, it's been there a while so the funky part is charming to me. I noticed that there were some regulars, employees fro the nearby hotels, that's a good thing. I had the steak and eggs with sour dough toast. Three scrambled perfect, hash browns (requested burnt) were crispy-perfect, steak...large for breakfast steak, a little too done but that's my fault, I asked for medium and I like rare. Toast, perfect... the service was so good, I went back to give the waitress a few more dollars-that's darn good! It's CASH ONLY so be ready for that. I'll be going back...
author: Rodney M.

description:
The food is really not that good. One Sunday morning I came in for breakfast and tried the huevos rancheros. The eggs were all right but the beans were hard. They weren't thoroughly cooked thru, preferring to serve it quickly rather than well.
I did give them another chance, coming in the following Sunday. I ordered the biscuits & gravy, but the gravy was so sour, I couldn't finish it.
author: Nat F.

description: At first when my husband and I walked into this restaurant it seemed friendly.    However,  after s few minutes we realized that was not a restaurant that deserved 3 stars.   The place looked like it needs a makeover. The seats were torn, etc, When I asked for straws for our drinks (3) they only gave us 1.   Our waitress was very friendly and made sure that we got our food quickly.  The food was ok but not great.  The thing that got me was when we went up to pay they told me that they only take cash.  They didn't tell me this until this time.  I told her that I didn't have any cash.  I was told that they had an ATM or I could leave my credit card with them until I came back with the cash.  I decided to use the ATM but there was a charge for it.  I told my waitress that she should have told me that they only take cash before we ordered.   The only sign that they have up saying that they only take cash is behind the front bar area.  My husband and I were so upset that we didn't leave a tip.
author: Elise D.

description:
No frills here.

Quick, simple cafe.

I ordered egg white vegetable omelette .
It was very crispy and greasy .

Not my usual preference, with it being so heavy on the oily side . but once In a while ok

they had great breakfast choice menu 

Staff were nice and friendly
author: Chloe L.

description: So far not impressed with wait staff. Owner is not friendly at all and if you don't know what you want she is very impatient. If you want a refill on coffee you must keep asking; and no this place was not crowded. The good was ok; I will say the French toast was very tasty, but quality of syrup very watery so it took away total flavor of f. toast.  Overall I will not recommend this place unless everything else is closed or crowded. Kind of like your last resort!
author: Kristina V.

description: No complains here, good food, good location, good service. People hustling to serve you fast and fresh made food. Great customer service, happy I started my day here
author: Livier V.

description: Big food low prices. This is a traditional Greek diner from Saturday night live.  Food is not going to be gourmet. But taste exactly the way it should for a diner. Cash only, TV in the corner & an old guy on the grill. Don't order anything "special" and stick with the strait up diner food & you're good.  Guys will like this place more than girls - it's in the reviews.
author: Leung T.

description: I would give this place no stars if I could.  It's dirty. The hash browns tasted like leather.   Cold coffee.  Service was poor and the place was not very clean.  Disappointing. I am been to many Greek cafes with excellent food and service.   This is not one of them by a long shot.  Don't waste your money.
author: tom j.

description: We had breakfast here two mornings in a row. It is just across the street from the Adagio Hotel on Geary St.  Very good food and friendly staff!!
author: Patrice H.

description:
If you're looking for a quick American-style breakfast with character, Olympic Flame cafe is it. The food is nice and greasy, yet delicious, and sure to fulfill your breakfast needs. I usually always go for pancakes and eggs, but the specials also look pretty delish. This place is underrated, as there's a competitor diner on the next block that gets a ton of business (that's not as good either, in my opinion). 

Not sure who runs the place, but every time I'm there, there seems to be someone barking orders to this lone cook, who churns out food like a General Motors assembly line. Definitely a must if you're staying on or near Geary street. 

Likes:
-quick food turnaround
-relatively cheap
-centrally located
-wide variety of menu offerings and specials

Dislikes:
-cash only (but they have a shady ATM onsite)
-looks a bit seedy/shady (but don't judge a book by its cover!)
author: Tracy T.

description: Awesome diner food with no frills and no pretentiousness. Old school cool and generous portions to boot. Come hungry!
author: Leo I.

description: Very good portion sizes and quality ingredients.  Reasonable prices.  Not the place if you are looking for the trendiest new cafe if you are trying to look cool but if you want good breakfast come here.
author: Jimmie L.

description:
If I could give a place SIX Stars I would to overtake these people who do not understand the concept. 
Was very happy with my French Bread Burger (with Bacon and Avocado). 
Lunch for myself and two friends came out to around $30.

The staff was nice and funny. 

Sadly they are not any standards on WHO is allowed to write a Yelp review. 
If you go into a place and expect Gary Danko, you may be disappointed. 

They are the types that write a review of an ocean side motel complaining about the sound of the waves. 

The owner/cook of the place is what I want to be at that age..

This place would be a good litmus test to see how high maintenance a date would be. 
If they complain about trivial/obvious things, you may want to extradite yourself from them.
author: Marcus R.

description: I love this diner. Great artichoke omelette. Friendly staff. Simple and cheap. One of the last old school diners left in the City.
author: stephan k.

description:
The only place that was open for breakfast around 7 am
Very good breakfast you can tell it's was cooked with love 
Fast service and big plates
author: Asi A.

description: Great neighborhood place for breakfast. Sumptuous portions, good service, reasonable prices, varied menu. There were dozens of specials to choose from not to mention the huge regular menu items. Eating here is sort of like eating at your grandmas house! Lots of locals as well as a varied international flair.
author: Barbara G.

description: Great place to go in the city if you looking for a good ol' diner breakfast! The service was fast and the people were friendly...good thing I had cash on deck tho because they will kindly direct you over to the ATM.
author: Brittney J.

description:
been to this place a few times and i am pretty sure i will keep going.
Breakfast is always good.
Bluberry pancakes and the biscuits and gravy are my favorite.
author: Michelle M.

description: My go to place in Union Square for breakfast. Cheaper than the trio of Cafe Mason, Lori's Diner, and the infamous Pinecrest Diner. Standard fare served up quick with a tad of bickering between the dedicated lady server and Executive Chef Uncle Louie. Cash only.
author: Frank L.

description:
Big country.

Huge man: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryant_Reeves

Huge plate: Two eggs, two chicken apple sausage links and one waffle substituted for pancakes by our friendly server at no charge. Extra $1 for egg whites.

For $10 it could have been two meals. Proved to be just one after an epic night dancing. Delicious all around. Off pink seats and throwback diner vibe were just as tasty.

Places like this are an endangered species. Would be a big loss to lose them.
author: Jason B.

description:
We stayed in the hotel across the street and after a night out we woke up late and wanted to find the closest and quickest breakfast. This place fit the bill. We had some halfway decent coffee, our mugs were refilled often. We ordered the spinach and sausage omelet and a gyro sandwich.  Both were good, the food was brought out in a timely manner, even though they were busy. 

The restaurant itself is a bit rundown, service is no frills, but decent. Everything did come to a screeching halt when I tried to pay with a credit card. There was no sign outside saying CASH ONLY.  Then I saw the ATM machine and realized they have it that way for a reason.

During our brief stay in San Fran, we used our credit card to pay for; parking, taxis, pizza slices, EVERYONE takes credit cards, Square has changed everything!  But the fact that they conveniently have an ATM machine makes me believe the owner has some kind of arrangement with the company that services the machine?  Anyways, minus two stars for the inconvenience and the $1.50 fee.
author: Raquel C.

description:
The place is run down and the waitress was charming. The food was nasty! The pancakes were rubbery and the sausage was gross. Orange juice taste like tang and they only carry slice bread. I was not happy. 

They only take cash which is sketchy. I was very disappointed with my sandwich, and hubby's pancakes. Coffee was not great either. 

Take the few minute walk to dine in a better breakfast spot.
author: ZG G.

description: Horrific.  Not sure how you can mess up an omelette, but wallaa.  Coffee tasted like cigarette water.  This may seem harsh, but I could only eat 1/4 of my omlette.
author: Justin Y.

description: This was hands down one of the worst breakfasts I've ever had. I'm all about a greasy spoon...but this was awful. Omelet was burnt. Chicken fried steak tasted like it started out frozen. Terrible terrible terrible. Waitress was nice, but that's about it.
author: Sean M.

description: This is absolutely the worst food quality service with a frown and tasteless food ever I have tasted breakfast here is the absolute worst it can be no star its not worth spoiling your mood day and stomach here stay away as far as possible !!!!
author: Patty T.

description: I went to Olympic fame cafe last week and has the biscuits and gravy. The serving was huge and they tasted great. My boyfriend had the breakfast burrito which was about the size of his full arm and it was also delicious
author: Christina G.

description:
This is a great place and exactly what SF needs more of to keep it affordable.    Really great omelette cooked perfectly and friendly service.   Coffee was decent and you are out the door for less than $15.....breakfast yesterday was $35!
Give this place a try, eat an omelette and let me know what you think!
author: Craig J.

description:
Initially comes off as charming hole in the wall but HA HA it's actually disgusting. 

I'm not a picky eater AT ALL, but for the first time in my life I just couldn't bring myself to eat the "omelette" I ordered. I would describe it as wet, flavorless, and also not an omelette-- it was more like a frittata or scramble kind of? Hot sauce could not save it. I decided to just eat my toast instead. Also flavorless. And cold. The waitress never brought me the coffee I ordered, instead refilling my boyfriend's and leaving the table. I would have reminded her but I never saw her again, until she noticed we were trying to pay and leave w/o eating hardly anything. 

Also- SURPRISE!- cash only.
author: Mandi S.

description:
Old school diner. Like mels diner but without the franchise. I came in here on a Thursday morning. The place closes at 4pm so I rarely see it open as I get up late. 

Waitress is very frank and attentive. Ask her about Russia. I had a three egg omelet which was delicious but could have had less grease. Made me feel nauseous but that was my own fault for finishing it. 

Less grease please and it'd be five stars.
author: Harry M.

description: The food was decent but that's about it. The server was pretty rude and even worse at the end they tell you oh, it's cash only. ..... Are you kidding me ? It's downtown SF in 2016 where even my church will let you pay with an app. Square readers are free. And you have to be insane to carry cash downtown, bums will rob you if you get within 4 feet. There is absolutely no excuse to not take payment with a card. I hate the new world order as much as the next American. But it's a matter of choice and personal safety here. Plus I need to be able to track expenses. So due to ATM frees I just payed this place 28$ for some bacon and eggs. Stay away until they  learn to take a card.
author: Scrapp H.

description:
If I could give any restaurant a 0, I would do so for this restaurant. My friends and I came here on a Sunday for breakfast. We originally wanted to eat at Tommy's, but unfortunately, they were closed until 11. We decided to give this place a try, which was a huge mistake!!! I really wished we checked the yelp reviews prior to eating here. My boyfriend and I ordered the NY Steak with scrambled eggs and potatoes. We asked for our steak to be cooked medium, but that's not what we were given. Instead, they cooked it well done. Not only was it cooked incorrectly, it was also very tough. It definitely wasn't quality meat! What made it worse was that we found a hair in our steak!!!! Soooo gross!!! And if you wanted to know what our eggs tasted like, it tasted like nothing. Super plain, no seasoning. 

My friends omelet was also a let down. She had only 2 bites and decided that the regular white bread toaat with butter was 100% better than her omelet. 

I will never come back! I'd rather starve than eat at this place! - yes, its THAT bad!!! Also, this place is dirty...
author: Jenifer L.

description:
We saw this family owned diner bang across hotel adagio. Though the reviews mentioned gallons of butter in the omelette, I just had to try this non commercialized establishment. 

Food - Omelette s are undoubtedly greasy. But surely is tasty and boy it does melt in your mouth.

Service - The single waitress looked over worked and grumpy. All she needed was a smile and some questions and she turned into this cheerful server.

Be patient in explaining your order as the folks do not seem to be fluent in English

Cost - $10 per pax.
author: Dipak S.

description: This place is GROSS!!! I would call the service horrible but it was more like non-existent. My group had to get our own straws, own refills and walk up to the counter to get our check...twice!! The burger had a weird spiced taste and the ketchup is watered down. The fries are undercooked, limpy, super oily and bland. I asked for no tomato...reiterated it again, and what do you know...there was tomato on the burger. My friend had eggs and said they were fine. Bleh.
author: Paige G.

description: The pancakes were fluffy, yet crispy. I've never had better scrambled eggs, I usually can't get through 2 and plowed them down before anything else. The club sandwich was delicious. Grandpa is at the grill and old school diner ambience. Cheap!
author: Holland R.

description: Service terrible. Got all orders all wrong. Maybe the worst breakfast I have ever had.  Are eggs supposed to be brown? Maybe they should wash their pans between making each entrée.  All our 4 dishes weren't worthy to feed to a dog.
author: Anthony V.

description:
*pout

I had just realized my camera was running on less than 20 minutes of battery time, so there had gone my hopes of spending some time looking for photo ops in the Tenderloin.  In addition, we had specifically looked forward to trying out another dive cafe (Dottie's True Blue) and upon departure from the 38, found the line snaking out the door.  Another stroke of doom on a Sunday morning.

With so much negativity, we opted to stroll downtown in order to, at the very least, take in the sunshine that was streaming between the various buildings and walls not stinking of leftover piss from the night shenanigans before.

Olympic Flame Cafe shares the same corner/alley with the Irish Castle, a charming establishment paying homage to everything Irish, and I remember the cafe only because I thought the signs out on Geary were a possibility to shoot.  Otherwise, my walk takes me past this cafe, probably due to the nondescript late 70's decor and lacking of any sort of creative twinkle to catch my eye.

Wrong.  It was during this moment of looking over the generic menu from the generic seat in the house, that the fellow tells me he thinks Jason Segel is at the counter.

"Who?" 

I don't know much about comedians but Apatow has been hitting my funny bone lately.  Seth Rogen?  What a cutie in my book.  Other than that, this Jason Segel character slips my mind.

"He was in Forgetting Sarah Marshall."

Never saw it.  The actresses in that film were not provocative enough to warrant spending money at the box office, although anything pixelated and no speech is the catalyst at my heels: Wall-E stole most of my attention that summer.  Once again, I notice that I am quite good at building disappointment and dashing male hopes prior to my first cup of coffee.  I shrug.  I'll run for a photo op if I see Clive Owen, Gerard Butler, or Monica Belluci, but in this case, I was playing the cool local indifferent to paying into the celebrity ooze.

Well, I was wrong.  Apparently it was Mr. Segel, in his unabashed sense of normalcy, standing at the counter.  With a baseball cap.  Fitting, to say the very least.  I was impressed.  He was in town to perform at Cobb's, as part of the Sketchfest series.  Neil Patrick Harris had dropped out per an SF article.  The dude was right.

After the first flush of recognition, I decided upon the special, which coincidentally was noted with a group of other specials listed neatly on the whiteboards posted above the grill.  The Chicken Sausage omelet, with green onions and mozzarella cheese.  This came with a nice scoop of their home fries and wheat toast, lightly toasted.  Add the side of mildly sedating coffee, and I finally felt that legal high that was needed to dispose of the previous disappointments.  $9.95?  The prices that go hand in hand with being situated so closely to the tourist square.  My legal high went down a notch.

The decor is reminiscent of some idiot deciding to go along with the changing times and unfortunately resulted in the typical rash decisions usually associated with mauve and burnt pinkish arrangements.  I was looking forward to the true greasy spoon dive cafe, with red vinyl seats, rupturing along the seams.  Not so here.  However, I was kept occupied with the comforting sounds of the cook's banter, the clinking of the spatula against the hot grill, and the Eastern bloc friendliness of the waitress keeping up with my empty cups of coffee.  If I'm in the neighborhood, I'll definitely try sitting at the counter next time.

At least I know that the stools swivel and when Gerard walks in, I'll be ready.
author: Miika M.

description:
My friend suggested going to Olympic Cafe for breakfast out of convenience. This dump was right across from our hotel. The cafe is dingy with old tables and slow wait staff. 

We were seated at the back of the restaurant, waited 20 minutes to waive down a waitress, she apologized for the delay and said she would come back. She came back 10 minutes later so we walked out. 

I'm glad I didn't get a chance to eat here because the place just looks dumpy.
author: Veronica H.

description: Classic greasy spoon.  Cash only no frills no nonsense.  Good omelettes good pancakes.  Atmosphere familiar but definitely its own thing.
author: Dave B.

description:
This was lunch with a show.  The Romanian waitress taking order from customer, not understanding the customer.  She then went to the Greek cook that was yelling at her.  The customer wanted eggs over hard. I think something was lost in translation at some point because the cook said they did not have hard boiled eggs.

When I asked if fries came with my Gyros and waitress did not know and asked the cook.  He again yelled NO!!!!   Maybe its just the way they communicate but I thought it was rather entertaining.   

The food was typical diner food.   I would go back their breakfast specials look awesome.
author: Kevin M.

description: Love this place. Old school, solid breakfast classics with no hip pretense. Totally awesome. My kind of place.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great Food, and service at a fair price.  Both the cook, waitress, and believe owner had a brief conversation with me in regards to their competition, and how they can offer more strawberries for a lot less.
author: Craig K.

description:
We were in search of Dottie's, where I had enjoyed many a breakfast in years prior.  I asked the owner of a mini mart on the corner where i remembered Dottie's being, and he said they moved to 6th and Market.  He recommended Olympic Flame Cafe close by for a good omelette.  He said the place has been around for 34 years.  

It's true, the place was old and casual, but with comfortable seats and a diner-y look and feel.  Framed photos of greece or italy that must have been hanging there forever, high on the wall, had only their cyan and yellow remaining visible to the eye. 

 the coffee was dinery, that is to say, a bit watery.  the "toast" was more like warm bread... could have been left a little longer in the toaster.  But the omelette was really good.  the waitress was the epitome of a diner server: fast-moving, loud-talking, but with attention given to the right things.  No bullshit, but friendly at the same time.  

It's not Dottie's, but it's fine for breakfast.  I will go back.
author: Stephen T.

description:
1/22/14 11:00am
Eggs Benedict with home fries.
2 Eggs Bacon and home fries.
Soda
Orange juice
Total $24.52 not including tip. 

Service was cool. Received drinks first then ordered. Food was promptly made and served. Food was ok. 
As far as the place goes, it's ok. Doesn't seem they have the budget yet to spruce it up a bit.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Terrible service. The place looks like it hasn't been renovated in years and there is a nice charm to it, but that's it. Food was served on dirty plates, the waitress was rude and inattentive to the customers, and the tables are dirty. 
Food wasn't anything that great either. Won't be coming back here again.
author: Alice K.

description: Solid cafe, nothing super special, takes only cash. Quick in and out kinda place.
author: Phillip T.

description: Food is okay, but they don't take credit cards.  Conveniently they have an ATM in the restaurant though.  SCAM!!!! Not impressed!
author: Sean N.

description:
Breakfast here was adequate -- nothing out of the ordinary and nothing bad.

The diner is a bit beat up in places. Furniture could have been replaced a while ago.

I found the eggs to be really good and so were the potatoes, sausage and toast.

This was a solid breakfast choice and the cost wasn't too bad.
author: Eric W.

description: Service excellent, severs are nice and friendly. Food really good and many options for a breakfast for champions. Price is a great deal.
author: Jose R.

description: Great breakfast place if you are staying at one of the nearby hotels. Chorizo eggs were excellent.
author: Rachel H.

description:
There's good reason for the low ratings from other yelpers.  This place makes Denny's seem like a 5 star dining experience.  The food is overpriced and service is lacking.  It seems like a family run business, but they're understaffed when it comes to waiting/service.  The food did come out relatively quickly, but getting refills on coffee was painful.  The food wasn't bad, although I tasted grittiness in my spinach scramble, presumably from not well washed spinach.  An 8oz glass of OJ for $4 is kind of what to expect.  Oh yeah, I did not find any indications that things were dirty.

There's a lot of business from the hotel guests nearby.  It's funny to see them looking at their phones, presumably checking the yelp ratings, and making a face before walking away.  I came in because I wanted to believe.  Next time down to the diner on Taylor.
author: Larry Z.

description:
WOULD definitely eat here again. To the previous reviewers that complained about price - breakfast is always expensive. If you want a "cheap" breakfast, go to Mcdonalds. If you want a good, "greasy spoon" place with a wide variety of menu options, check this place out. 

Homemade corned beef hash! So hard to find. And VERY tasty. 

Yes, the one waitress is a little "battle axe-y" but she's actually very nice. Just efficient at what she does. 

Very clean, tasty food, quick on coffee refills, quick delivery of food. It was a packed house at 830am in the morning of Bay to Breakers. 

FYI - CASH ONLY restaurant. There is an ATM inside.
author: Julie S.

description: Just so happened to walk by, so my husband and I went on for a late breakfast. I got the breakfast combo, and it was great. My husband got the chicken fried steak and he loved it. The service was a little slow. But other than that, I loved it!
author: Carly C.

description: Had breakfast today. A little pricey but it is SF.  Pancakes were awesome.  Owner does the cooking. He said 57 years at the griddle!
author: KS B.

description: Good menu, good prices, good food, but the service left a little to be desired. They definitely weren't in a hurry to refill drinks, and my wife didn't get her food until we were all almost done eating. Would have given it 3 stars if I had come by myself - my eggs weren't seasoned at all with salt or pepper. My hot links were delicious and potatoes okay. But the kids LOVED theirs and I tried the French toast, it might be the best I've ever had. Light and fluffy, and totally delicious. Boy had the chocolate chip pancakes and he ate every bite. So, if you can get past the slow service this is a good place for breakfast on the cheap.
author: Brandon E.

description: I want to give 3 and a half but four is close enough. Really good prices for decent food. I've eaten a variety of food here. The staff are prompt but the restaurant could use a deep cleaning. Really convenient so I go occasionally..
author: nancy w.

description: I thought the eggs were good, service ok, coffee good,  potatoes were good the corned beef hash was really oily and not good.
author: N P.

description:
I came here prior to my date with the "Dark Knight."

I wanted to eat at Dottie's, but my empty stomach couldn't wait in that long line. So I went around the corner and there is another breakfast joints for tourist. 

To nobody's surprise, this diner is also crowded, but bigger than Dottie's. With the diner being crowded, I was forced to sit at the end of the counter near the kitchen, where an amigo was washing the dirty dishes.

I had the Northwestern Scramble. For $8.50, you get  chopped salmon, cream cheese and chives scrambled with three eggs. My meal also comes with home fries, toast and an endless refill cup of coffee. The customized scrambled eggs tasted like a Noah's Bagel with Lox and Cream cheese with eggs. I guess that's why they called it a "Northwestern." Luckily with me sitting at the end of the counter near the dishwasher, no dirty water splashed into my meal. 

The food was ok, but the service was a bit rough with one of the twin waitresses are a little bit on the mean side. The busy restaurant is as expected dirty and flies/mosquitoes hovering over the facility. 

If you come here, it's "Cash only" and dine with precaution, despite the Health score of 92. As dirty as this place seems, I feel optimistic about that score given by the Health Dept. Also a favorite of Yelp, with the sticker on the glass door. Imagine that?
author: Matt G.

description: Awesome cheap breakfasts and they also filmed the documentary about the Compton's Cafeteria riot here!  (Queer riot that happened before Stonewall...)
author: Kooky B.

description: Ah; I LOVE this place! Real east coast vibe to it. I can't wait for my next trip back!
author: Tony D.

description:
We checked this place out as it was conveniently located across from Hotel Adagio and the reviews seemed pretty good. 

This place is not the healthiest food but man was it good. As soon as you walk in you are enticed by the smell of bacon cooking and it sure makes your mouth water. I had the french toast with scrambled eggs and sausage and it was delicious. As mentioned, the food is not the healthiest  and there might be some suspicious handling practices - but the real downer was the service.

We tried this place out on our vacation with some family and when we walked it was pretty quiet and calm. The Asian lady was our server and she seemed real nice with us and our little ones. She walked by pretty often and asked if we needed anything else. We were taking our time, as we were on vacation, and there was a complete 180 when it started getting busier. 

Our server kept giving us the stink-eye as we were just hanging out and talking while drinking coffee. She kept looking at us every 2 minutes to see if we were leaving and came by twice to ask if we had gotten our check and/or needed anything else. 

I understand that there was limited seating but don't make feel like you are longer wanted because you ate and paid.
author: Marco H.

description: Horrible service! The waitress anastasia was very rude with all the staff around her and she was condescending with the dishwasher I felt sorry for him and this all happened right in front of me! She didn't mind guests hearing what a total b!tch she was. So I called her out on it before I left. I was outraged. Food is mediocre I Def would not recommend
author: Javier D.

description:
The cockroach in my omelette was very yummy thank you i will eat here a gain.  
not.

I ordered the San Francisco special omelette.  Apparently it was the tenderloin special.
author: Matt N.

description:
Basic greasy spoon - nothing fancy at all.  I had the all meat omelette and it was basically ham, bacon and sausage in a three egg omelette. Something that could be made at home in a few minutes.
Strange thing was my wife and I felt like we walked into a funeral home.  There wasn't a single smile on anyone's face that worked there.  I jokingly said it looked like the staff all received a notice that the store was closing in a week or something.  
The restaurant really needs a makeover, there are large "machines" of some sort next to the seats with dirty/dusty vents, the seats are torn, the tables were dirty, and the seat that I sat in was missing a divider to separate both sections.  So basically a two person spot was a four person spot unintentionally.  Would I go back?  Only if every other spot in the area was too packed or closed.
author: Steve M.

description:
don't know what the bad reviews are about, but I'm giving them five stars for quick service, being patient when I was talking on the phone with someone, and the cool himself came out and asked if the food (i ordered myself a vegetarian omelette, with a side of potatoes and toast) was up to my liking... of course I said yes. it was absolutely delicious! born and raised here all my life and just found out about this "hole in the wall" sort of place and was happy to find out that they not only out out really good food, but it's a great price. 

also, breakfast served all day for those that decide to roll outta bed in the afternoon.

invite yourself in, don't be afraid. it's a small place, yes, but it's worth every penny.
author: Jenn N.

description:
This is our second time here and we will not be returning. It's unfortunate because I love small diner places and the bf lives about 2 blocks away. But the service is horrible. We were seated for 15 min before we were even greeted. They were busy so I tried to understand. I then saw our server handle money in one hand and the toast (bare handed) in the other. Disgusting. 

Always love an old school diner joint but I saw so many health code violations on this visit it will be my last.
author: Natalie D.

description:
This place is what it is: a greasy spoon. My gigantic Western omelet was surprisingly tasty (for what I was expecting - a cheap greasy omelet). The onions were carmelized and they used red peppers instead of green, which was a nice touch. 

The place is a classic dive, the cook is ancient, the server is not stoked to be there, but they serve what they serve, and if you're looking for something gourmet, this ain't the place for you. 

Decent. Large. Greasy. 

And cash only.
author: Don B.

description: Yes, the place is a bit dumpy, but if you like "greasy spoon" spots - this is it! It is a very old school style cafe with tasty breakfast. We liked our waitress, she was very no nonsense and  pretty much ran the place, but was still friendly.  We had omelets off the current specials list, and both were quite tasty. They come with fried potatoes which had a bit if a bacon flavor to them - yummy!
author: Tami J.

description:
WORST COFFEE I've ever had. Not fit for human consumption. Cream container for milk was filled with either watered down milk or skim.

 Waitress hard to understand. Food was mediocre.

I paid the price for not Yelping first!
author: Richard L.

description: Good food at great prices.  We had regular breakfasts, all were good.  Cheerful, attentive staff.   If you are looking for fancy decor, not your place.  But if you want good food and service, this is your place.
author: Calvin M.

description: Great breakfast . Had chicken fried steak.  Covered is a awesome gravy . I will go back again . Great service
author: Audrey R.

description:
I really like this place for breakfast. It seems to be family-run with grandpa at the grill and the granddaughters waiting tables. 

I wasn't expecting much from a diner, but the food is quite good. I've tried two vegetarian omelets (with egg whites only) and they both were well-cooked, tasty and served promptly. 

Service is quick and efficient, prices are reasonable and the clientele is a mix of locals and tourists. 

My only complaint: After several coffee refills, they stopped, giving me the impression that I had sat around reading my book just a little too long. No one was waiting and I would've liked to hang out a  bit longer.
author: Kim C.

description:
Checked this out for breakfast. Decent typical American fare. Nothing mindblowingly special.

Problem was the waitress had an attitude that varied from pissed off to attentive. It's like she's bipolar. Even had the audacity to ask "whether we saw the bill" when I handed her $50 for a $43 bill. That's right. I saw the bill and I tipped your establishment accordingly. You got over 15%. You're not getting 20% or more without an improvement in attitude and taste.
author: BB H.

description: Good food. Get in get out. Ample and basic. Lovely waitress deals well with mixed clientele, ie: Europeans. Not super clean for you phobes. I would come back!
author: Larry M.

description: Yes, the place looks like it hasn't been renovated since the 1950s, but it kinda adds to the charm.  Once you get past that, order the Gyros sandwich. It is so damn delicious.  The lamb is tender and tasty and the pita is very fresh - they say homemade and I believe it.  Slow service but the Gyros made up for it.
author: M. G.

description: I'm pretty sure the man at the grill is probably older than time itself, but he makes some damn good food. This is my favorite greasy spoon in all of San Francisco and possibly the world. I have the guys in my lab working on the secret of immortality just so I can continue to have the delicious food the owner puts out.
author: Pete C.

description:
This is a diner. A diner sometimes has poor service. A diner sometimes has weird patrons. I just simply do not understand why people have such high expectations from a diner. 

So, the pancakes, yeah, they are crazy good. I have waited in line at Dottie's and had a good breakfast, but walking right into this place and getting hot, fluffy, tasty pancakes presented to me within 15 minutes really does it for me. I kinda wanted to keep it to myself, but the bad reviews pissed me off.
author: Kim B.

description:
Okay the setup. Like everyone else we were overflow traffic from Dotte's which you can spit to from Olympic. We took one look at Dotte's line and I took my introspective blood sugar reading and decided we should try Olympic since they did have a Yelp sticker. 

Walk in and we're seated. The women takes our order and I start with an oj. It ends up that the oj is that watered down crap you get at 7-11, I saw it when she poured it. My heart fell on the floor and I was crushed. I hate that kind of oj. It's so bad, so lame that a b-fast place serves it. 

I ordered the jumbo breakfast, I was really hungry by this point even ready to eat my own fingers soon! First my toast comes out, odd, it gets cold while I wait for my eggs to come which I use to dip in my egg yoke for goodness. Food comes a couple minutes later, but now my toast is cold :(. I cry internally. My eggs were ordered over-easy they look over easy, but they are half cooked, gooey eggs, not fully cooked, would be approriate for a casear salad maybe but not my bfast. The only pepper option is the tasteless pepper shaker, I hate that too. Negativity keeps adding up. 

My sadness continues, I thought it was over at the oj. My friends bacon looked like it had been sitting for a few hours on a hot plate, not very enticing. The homefries were non-toxic, that's about the best thing I can say about them. 

Overall, I rather of have gotten a powerbar. I wouldn't come back. If you're too hungry to think, you should still skip it, I wish I had :).
author: Michael S.

description:
Greasy Spoon Cafe with all the authentication you need to live up to that name. A perched corner cafe where literally tons of folks flawk in and out. It's 10am maybe later and I'm hungover and STARVING. What I thought would be a quick waltz to the overly famed, Dottie's True Blue Cafe, I was let down. 5'3" and hungry, my grateful and gracious soul could not find the wittz to wait around for 40 minutes maybe more to eat. As disappointment seeped in and my frustration grew more irrational with each step, we find "Olympic Fame." 

Nicely walked in grabbed a table, the waitress of one with a Full House. Not only could sense our desperation to be fed. She was so attentive that I felt like people were giving us evil looks like "I was here first, who the hell are you!" 

I was at this point of my order so gun ho on food, I literally over ordered. I even ordered not thinking I ordered. (probably in delirium.) The hash superb, eggs on point and with substitutions, and the waffles for which I protest I did not order but apparently did. ALL WORTH IT! Well spent $10!

Next hangover, screw waiting in line. My first and only choice "OLYMPIC FLAME!"
author: Sera F.

description: The breakfast here is GREAT. Get the chocolate chip french toast. YUMMY!!!  The steak omelet,  which my GF haf, she was drooling over. If you are downtown, or staying downtown from out of town, although it doesn't look good on the eyes, it will make your a.m. tummy super happy.
author: Anthony C.

description:
I have been coming here for over 20 years ,the omelettes and potatoes are amazing. I love the old sf ambiance. i just wish joe would offer some more new items like real salads options like healthy smoothies. its quite a show when you sit up on the front with the tv on and joe speaking to the waitresses and flipping his pancakes!
The ttuna melt is grilled and delicious. these days i am getting white egg omlettes and they are still delicious
author: Patti M.

description: A local breakfast joint that feels family owned and caters to the locals vs. tourists.  It's open at 6am, so nice to pre-order via phone, grab breakfast and head to the office.  I have had good attentive service and the food has been good.  Their coffee is great as well.   Cash only though!   Also, I would bump to a 4 star possibly if they served hash browns (love) vs. home fries.
author: Neville B.

description:
PRO:  Exactly what you expect from a greasy-spoon diner.

CON:  Exactly what you expect from a greasy-spoon diner.
author: Jason M.

description:
We dropped off our Subaru for warranty work at Putnam Subaru at 640 O'Farrell.  Since it was early, we decided to go to breakfast.  We walked past Dottie's on Jones Street, but that was closed on Tuesday.  One of the locals in the area, walking a muzzled pit bull, told us to try the Olympic Flame Cafe.  He said it was the next best restaurant in the area and warned us not to walk further into the Tenderloin area.

We took his recommendation and arrived at the Olympic Flame.  The place looked clean and the prices reasonable for being on the edge of the Union Square area.  We sat in a comfortable booth and I had the country breakfast consisting of 4 pieces of link sausages, two eggs, and a couple of pancakes.  They even had sugar free syrup.  I was comfortably full after my meal.

The other order was a vegetarian omelet consisting of bell peppers, onions, tomatoes, zucchini, and cheese.  It was served with country potatoes and two pieces of toast.  It was more than one person could eat.

Both of these meals were about $8-$9 each.  It was tasty and the service was good.  The decor had pictures of Greece and it looked like a family run business. The prices aren't too bad. When you walk closer to Union Square, the prices escalate and those places probably cater to the unsuspecting tourists. In general, this place is good and homey and is not a greasy spoon as some critics have written.
author: Robert J.

description: The omelettes are the best, I always go with the avocado, bacon and cheese. Soooo good!
author: Gustavo C.

description: This place was gross!! I was willing to try it because of how close it was but the whole place was dirty, the cooks used the knives they were cooking with to cut open boxes but never got rid of the knife. Food sat out on really small counter spaces while waiting for the servers to get it and the food was touching shelves and other things. Definitely a health inspectors nightmare! The food itself (yes I did it eat it because i was hungover and starving) was more greasy than you could imagine! and I didn't think you could mess up scrambled eggs bacon and toast but they sure did! DO NOT GO HERE!
author: Zachary B.

description: Good comfort food at a good price. True the atmosphere was "worn", but not as bad as others would have you believe. We were only people in the place just after opening on a Sunday and the waitress was very personable. Would go back again.
author: Bob K.

description:
LOL at the hungry idiots in line at Dottie's, Brenda's, or all the way at Mama's.  Suckas.

I could get my "egg-white-only San Francisco scramble with Chicken sausage instead of ground chuck" and make my way over to all three lines, before I'd even be seated if I were to be in one of them .  I've been to all three ridiculously hyped up and claustrophobia-inducing places countless times and honestly, if you're just hungry for breakfast, Olympic Flame Cafe will make you happier, a lot faster.  

An egg is an egg...is an egg.

Plus, they serve breakfast all day.
author: Tokki M.

description:
This was my first restaurant in San Francisco, and probably the worst. The place was next to empty when we went in for a midday meal, which should have been the first hint.

The service is what it is. Nothing particularly grating about it, but nothing particularly pleasant, either.

My friend and I both ordered omelets, and what we got weren't omelets in any real sense of the word. Sub-par ingredients were haphazardly mixed in with an amorphous, tasteless pile of overcooked eggs. The hash browns weren't any good either, and the whole shebang was more expensive than most informal meals to be had in this city.

Avoid, avoid, avoid.
author: Tracy C.

description:
Just what you need for a greasy breakfast.  Prices are very reasonable and the omelet's had meat throughout the eggs, not just stuffed all in a blob in the middle.

This is not high-scale, but is your good old diner type breakfast, with seating booths and counters. 

Cash only, but they do have an ATM, so be prepared for that.
author: Jeff S.

description: Horrible service and even worse food. Corned beef hash tasted stale. What a huge disappointment.
author: Brandy N.

description:
My friend and I were aiming for Dottie's, but when we were unpleasantly surprised by the fact that they are closed on Tuesdays (WTF?), we sauntered around the corner so as not to waste the parking meter money.  

The options looked slim to none, but as we approached Olympic Flame's sign, we saw what appeared to be a variety of breakfast options.  We quickly agreed that if there were people inside eating that we would take a gamble.  As my friend said, "What's the worst that can happen."  

Ugh.  It literally was the worst food I've EVER been served in San Francisco.  The eggs...yuck.  I ordered them scrambled because I LOATHE runny whites, and in a new joint, you can never be too sure that one man's "over medium" is what I would call "snotty albumen."  However, the scrambled eggs smelled off, and they tasted like they had been grilled in rancid grease.  I took one bite and left them on the plate...never in my life have I done that.  Also, the coffee is pretty rank...we're talking early 80s truck stop coffee.  Blech.

So, the bill comes, and it's $25+ for rank eggs (my friend couldn't even eat the omelet because of the same indescribable issue with the eggs).  Luckily, the waitress, whom I gather is rather new, was very kind.  She saw that we hadn't eaten the eggs, and she reduced the tab.
author: Julie T.

description:
Attention SF business owners and restauranteurs!

Fact: there is a line out the door of Dottie's every morning.

Fact: there is nothing remotely as good for breakfast nearby.

Fact: American breakfast food is not hard to get right.

Solution: open a Dottie's knock-off nearby! You'll make a mint! The Olympic Flame (very possibly the worst restaurant name ever) is not the solution, and is part of the problem. I'm back to waiting in line at Dottie's.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Oh Dear God, FAIL.

After convincing my parents the other morning to finally get out of the tourist trapped Wharf and head out to a place I had found on Yelp (Farm:Table) we were greeted with only that, a table and ZERO butt room.

So now I look like the asshole, and "Were in the middle of nowhere now" starts coming from my parents whom are obviously twisting the blade.

I then look down the street and see a gigantic BREAKFAST sign and at this point, I don't care how bad it is, just anything to get my Dad off my ass.

Olympic was rather empty - not good. 

Also the floors acted a dual role as a ice rink as they were VERY VERY slippery (most likely from all the grease and staff failing to clean them on a regular basis)

I ordered my staple, sausage and eggs with toast....a dish that should NOT be hard to mess up, however much like the extremely uninviting "eco bulb filled" ceiling the dish came out tasting like absolute ass.

Sausage was extremely overseasoned, eggs were runny (asked for medium) and toast was just bad in all sense. 

I don't know what was worse, the urine filled toilet in the bathroom that someone failed to flush or the fact that the bill was over 50 dollars.

Yuck.
author: Patrick O.

description: Great buckwheat pancakes with blueberries!  Northwestern scramble was delicious with smoked salmon. The place is clean, the waitress attentive and friendly. I recommend it!
author: Guiseppe V.

description:
I walk by the Olympic Cafe every morning and the smells that waft out of there are enough to drive me crazy at 6:00AM! I want to dive head first through the door in to a booth and order one of their mouth watering omelets they so blatantly advertise. 

This morning I got my opportunity. With my family in town we needed a place where we didn't need to wait for a table (of course Dotti's had a line down the block). Ya know, this place was pretty damn good for a diner. 

My mom and I shared the corn beef and hash which was pretty good (nothing compared to Perry's) but the real highlight of the meal was their blueberry pancakes! Typically pancakes at places like this are mediocre at best but these were right up there with some of the better brunch spots! Why the three star rating then? The coffee tasted like watered down mud and they prepared our eggs way too runny. Service was a tad on the slow side; it took us a while to get our food but I'm chalking that up to the fact that there were 5 of us. 

All-in-all, I'd definitely come back here again to order their pancakes. I'd just make sure to bring coffee from somewhere else.
author: Julia N.

description: If I'm in the mood for a greasy, heavy breakfast, this is where I go. Yes, I do crave for sloppy grease sometimes. I can't help it! Pork chops and eggs were my usual...and I loved it! Other breakfast dishes have left me less enthused. Their chicken apple sausage, I don't know what that was. I know I said I like it greasy sometimes, but that overly salted, oily, rough meat patty is not what I was looking for. Are you sure that wasn't pork? Would pork sausages have been better? Eh, I guess I have to stick with that ONE dish that I know is good.
author: Helen L.

description:
You know, I would say go here just to try out a new experience. Because sometimes it's fun to throw a little curve ball into your day, get the chutzpa amped and moxie juiced. (Yeah, that was for you Katy H and Christina Y.)

The waitress was all bunny happy and smiles. Ok, not really, but maybe she was having a bad day ... she did after all say "excuse me."

Well, it was more like "excuse me, EXCUSE ME," as she delivered my food and discovered she would have to set it down somewhere other than on my computer - which if we're talking usable space, equaled about 70 percent of the table.

If there was a theme to the things I ordered, it was likely "just add water." The coffee, orange juice and even the oatmeal were watered down. Mmmm, nothing like baby food before 8 a.m. to make you chipper. The bananas (oatmeal topping) were the highlight - and I will admit that with some whipped butter and brown sugar, I had a few tasty bites.

The service was fast, but in a way that was more like a race where the end goal is time and not service.
author: Olivia L.

description:
We wanted to go to Dottie's True Blue Cafe around the corner but saw the line so we detoured and found this place.  Wish I had seen Matt N's review ( Be sure to read his review). I would never of stepped a foot in the door.  
We had usually breakfast fare.  It was okay, we didn't get sick from it or find anything extra special added to the dish.   Sevice was okay.  Waitress was nice.   By the time we left most tables were full.   
Try for something better and skip this place just in case they get a new crop of cockroaches.
author: Marla G.

description: Love it! I know it's nothing special but the quality is consistently good, friendly service and no line. It's for when I'm too lazy to make my own breakfast but not necessarily a place to bring a guest. Just my go-to, down to earth, greasy-spoon breakfast place.
author: Jamie Starr X.

description:
Even as a hole in the wall diner, this place disappoints. The service was kind of slow. The prices weren't great, and the food. . . sigh. The only thing keeping them from getting 1 star is that their coffee was drinkable and they cooked my over light eggs correctly. Otherwise the toast was cold, the waffle was dry and crispy, and the corned beef hash was canned and burnt. And for some reason the orange juice was kept in reused gallon jugs which means that the OJ is from concentrate and that they are reusing plastic containers not meant for reuse. And they don't take credit cards.

First and last visit.
author: rob. l.

description: It's the perfect greasy spoon for basic breakfast food and burgers!  Easy way to feed hungry teens at a low price.  The eggs, pancakes and meat were all fine.  The family run atmosphere makes this a gem compared to the soulless plastic menu restaurants or stuffy generic hotel food.   The place has minimal decor and shows its age, so please don't come here thinking it's an upscale dining experience.  It's warm food at a relatively cheap price.
author: B W.

description: Service was slow, food ok and they don't serve half and half with their coffee. Cash only. Three strikes one ball.
author: Jay D.

description: Never take a restaurant recommendation from a homeless man. We came here because every place yesterday had a line for breakfast. This place is gross. We ordered breakfast and then I saw a cockroach crawling on the wall. I couldn't eat my food, but my husband didn't seem to care, so I watched him eat while trying not to vomit. I'm still nauseated by the cockroach image that is forever burned in my brain. The server was at least nice...
author: Jackie S.

description:
I just noticed a slew of bad reviews so I know you've been warned. Here's mine anyway:
I had been here before and I remembered they had omelets which is what I wanted.  Although the place was less than half full, the service was still bad; It took over a half hour to get my food.  During that time a guy walked in, sat at the counter and was mosttly done eating before I even got my order.  I ordered a chorizo, mushroom and swiss cheese omelet.  When it finally came it wasn't an omelet; they just scrambled it all together. I looked down and said "This isn't an omelet". At first the waitress started to tell me some excuse. I'm not sure exactly what she said.  Then she asked if I wanted them to redo it.  I told her it took 40 minutes to get and I didn't want to wait another 40 minutes.  I ate the meal.  It was edible and I was hungry.  
Caveat emptor on this one.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I am both surprised and not surprised at the low reviews for this place. Not surprised, as many of them are from "foodies" who normally wait an hour in line to eat at Dottie's. This is a greasy spoon, a hole in the wall diner. There isn't much on the menu that will leave you feeling good about your health afterwards and it won't make you feel that you are a sophisticated or cultured city dweller.

I always get one of the omelettes because they are humongous and fluffy and flavorful and hearty for a decent price. My BF gets the French Toast Trio, cause that's his thing. We are always incredibly satisfied after, though I will admit that they aren't exactly reinventing breakfast. But sometimes that is all I really want/need.

The prices are on par with nearly every diner (and when I say diner I mean diner, not cafe or bistro) I've ever eaten at, and I never got the sense that this place was filthy or gross. Maybe I'm not scrutinizing my surroundings close enough, but it seems perfectly clean to me. Not exactly stylishly decorated, but I'm used to places in the TL looking like this. The tables I sit at are always clean and the utensils and dishware are always clean, and early in the morning that is all I'm capable of processing.

I will agree with the other reviewers who said the service was a bit slow, but they always seem to be pretty busy when I come in, so I cut them some slack.

In summation: though the omelettes have surprising variety, most of the food is your standard, greasy diner fare, so come here if you're into that (I totally am). Entrees are all under $10, I believe, and the service is slow but not excruciating.
author: Trish B.

description:
If you come here wishing for Dottie's but the line drove you away, but you really wanted Dottie's, you'll be sad.  

Now that that's out of the way, Olympic is a dandy place for what it exactly is: greasy spoon, spare interior, businesslike servers, grizzled dude at the grill (sit at the counter to watch them cook your breakfast), big-ass breakfasts that won't destroy your wallet for the rest of the day. Siddown, read the leftover paper, watch the news or game on the tube in the corner, and eat your vittles.

PS If you sit at the counter try to avoid the very end toward the back. It's next to the back room with the sink and stuff, and I'm just saying...
author: Otay B.

description:
This place has the no-pretension diner feel, the kind of neighborhood place that seems low key and comfortable. 

However, from the food to the service, this place was AWFUL! 

The coffee tasted like double brewed coffee filter. And when she brought me the coffee, no cream. I got up to ask her for some, and she pointed to the cream sitting on the counter that obviously someone else had used. 

She got the order wrong: eggs florentine instead of eggs benedict. And maybe I shouldn't have ordered e.b., but it came out all dripping with ooozie butter sauce that was sickening and greazy. 

The bill was about $26 for two.
author: Car C.

description: Updating to 4 stars because they are so cool about letting us take up a booth for hours  ... just talking, laughing, hanging ... and sucking down cup after cup of coffee.  The sweet waitress just smiles and offers more.
author: Rosie M.

description: This is a no nonsense diner that serves plenty of artery clogging food and the decor seems like the booths haven't changed since the 60s. By my rating, that is a good thing. Upon entering you'll be seated immediately and coffee fix fulfilled. French Toast, Pancakes, Waffles, and Omelettes are what's on tap here. Be sure to check the dry erase boards to see what the specials are. Oh yeah, the prices here are ultra cheap and the service here is pretty good as well. If you are a pretentious eater or want to eat healthy, don't come here and bitch because you've been warned. For those that might have a hangover or just wants some grease  don't be scurrrred.
author: Steve A.

description: I stopped in here after attempting to get squeezed in for a haircut at Public Barber next door (attempt failed, but I got a space for the next day) -and I had a pleasing and hefty breakfast. 3-egg omelette with avocado, mushrooms, spinach, & cheese and house potatoes and wheat toast. Also ordered a cup of coffee - the waitress wasn't overly attentive, but she did check in with me to refill my coffee and ask if everything was okay. Overall, excellent and filling breakfast. Comparable to Denny's, but way bigger portions...my total tab was a little over $11.
author: Elaine W.

description:
I used to go to Olympic Cafe all the time as a kid, it was great, great service.

On my recent trip to Olympic Cafe I was unpleasantly surprised. The waitress didn't acknowledge us, when we finally flagged her down she said I'll be there rudely. It took about 20 minutes for us to not even order. 

We Walked out. I suggest you not ever come here. This kind of service is unacceptable as a restaurant. They changed the owner from before, you minds well go out of business. Good Luck assholes!
author: Steven C.

description:
I was in San Francisco for the weekend celebrating The Big Man's office party. On Sunday morning we thought about going to breakfast at Dottie's, then thought again when we spied the line at 9:00. We came to the Olympic Flame Cafe instead and it was fine. Not mind-blowing, not haute cuisine, not innovative. It's a dive cafe in the real sense of the word. Formica tables in faded gray. Booths that have seen more than their fair share of little slices of life. A jaded looking bunch in the open kitchen, and a world weary waitress. The stories are all there, folks.

We had our wits about us and stayed with the basics, and they didn't disappoint. I had scrambled eggs, bacon, and potatoes. They were perfectly acceptable. Stuart had eggs over medium, potatoes, and half a grapefruit. If this is a destination for you, well, have at it! If Dottie's or Ella's is more your cup of tea, you've been warned, and you have no room to complain. So...you choose. It's a fine enough joint!
author: Suzanne F.

description:
I really don't understand the reviews on this place.  Some people are comparing it to Dottie's True Blue, which has been, since it opened, the best breakfast place in S.F.  Period.  Unfortunately, the other diner type eating places in this area are typically like this.  Mediocre hit and miss diner food at OK prices (not cheap).  If you want Dottie's, put up with the wait.  It's that good.  If you do not, and don't want to head to No. Beach, to Mama's, the 2nd best place for breakfast in the city, well, you'll have to walk to HRD in SOMA, or a few blocks away, try Golden or Han's.  They are cheaper and a bit better.  Otherwise, this is what all the places around this area are like.  I don't think they (the proprietor's) should feel that they are any different from the other spots around there, even Taylor St. Coffee Shop, which has a little better reviews and might be slightly better.  

It is what it is!
author: Patti H.

description: Good food at a great prices. I highly recommend the ome.lettes and soups.
author: Niki B.

description:
So let's talk about Olympic Flame Cafe while we are only a few days away from the Olympic Games :)

A local long-standing place that serves cheap breakfast. They have a chalkboard of "Specials" (not sure how often they actually update it. Maybe they simply do not update the paper menu)...

Breakfast was so so, passable, a bit heavy for breaky. Also, they don't like when you ask for substitutes and will simply say, "No" without offering other alternatives and with a straight face. Kinda a place with an attitude. The place did not seem to be too clean, but maybe it's just the old floor.
author: T L.

description:
Also known as the Olympic Cafe (flame off!), this diner is much better than your average greasy spoon. While the wait staff is a little slow -- and somewhat surly, almost surprised that you're still there -- the food is a step or two up from your run-of-the-mill diner in the U.S. My friend and I have a theory: San Francisco is such a foodie town that even the greasy spoons have to be above par.

Rick got the omelet with Italian sausage, feta, and green onions. It came with potatoes and toast. I got the breakfast burrito with ham, which came drizzled with melted cheddar cheese and the littlest amount of salsa. I asked for a little bowl of salsa -- which turned out not to be the best salsa -- and it improved the burrito immensely.

With coffee and OJ, our bill came to $23, which is on the high side for a greasy spoon, as well. Just goes to show. In San Francisco, the average is above average. For foodies -- and for people working near the Civic Center.
author: Heath R.

description:
People, this place isn't Dottie's.  This place isn't Canteen.  This isn't Boogaloo's.  It doesn't belong in Union Square;  if it were in my neighborhood we would eat here four times a week and love it and it would have five stars solid.   But its in Union Square and suffers the low star consequences.    

This is a fucking awesome greasy spoon diner with strong coffee, crunchy hash browns, and they don't skimp on the cheese or the avocado in the omelets.
author: Nora B.

description:
Wow, I should have gone to Burger King or Ihop. For 8.99 I expect an omelet to have something in it that hasn't been preserved in a can. I expect the waitress to smile at least once and hand a menu to me within 7 minutes of entry. I'm grateful I even got a coffee refill. Good thing I don't mind tasters choice. 

If you're going to go anyway, I say stay away from the Chicken Apple Sausage omelet. It was disgusting. Putting spam in it would have tasted better than their "sausage."  The floors were dingy, gritty, dirty, and so was the food and service. 

1/2 a star if I could.
author: Sharmet S.

description:
Needing food badly and seeing the lines snaking out of other nearby restaurants, dreading them, really, a very nice man who happened to be relaxing on the sidewalk offered up "Go to Olympic, two blocks up" 
Seated immediately. Yay. Yay ends here. 
Scary half-booth with a very nice couple on the other side. The booth partition was missing so it was like we were dining together.  Meeting new people over breakfast?  Umm, not today. They hated it as much as we did. No, they hated it more. 
Service was a mess. We sat w only water for a good 20 minutes before my coffee and our menus showed up, then perhaps another 20 to order, and only then bc I flagged somebody down. She said our waitress wasn't available, and that she was so sorry. Really? Ten more minutes pass, I flag her down again and she agrees to take our order. Didn't matter bc she apparently never passed it off to the cooks bc a good solid 30 minutes later, when flagged down for status & updates she says "Oh, you didn't get it yet?" 
No. 
Add 15 minutes. 
The food arrives. It's wrong. I don't care. I will eat anything at this point, I'm not waiting any longer. Umm, except that burnt toast, boo. And there's no tabasco. 
Insult to Injury: I flag her down (again!) for the bill and pass off the credit card. "Cash only, we've an ATM." 

The food was actually ok, despite being not what I ordered. But no hashbrowns! 
Not worth it.
author: Meg W.

description:
back from lunch and almost too full to type....I'm always weary of places that serve breakfast all day, don't know why. But if you are gonna serve me pancakes for lunch you better bring it. 
I'm a pancake aficionado, i know my 'cakes man and this place did a solid job. slightly grr...for charging extra for chicken apple sausage, but it is slightly understandable. 
my eggs were greasy like Travolta in Saturday night fever greasy, but I'm hungover, so no complaints. 
Solid choice in the t-loin when you want breakfast for lunch or breakfast for breakfast.  
Reccos: 
Breakfast combo
Joe's special
grilled cheese w/ avocado and tomato
author: Gabe b.

description:
Your average greasy spoon joint! For a cheap omelet near Union Square go here. 
Big portions and somewhat stinky but a good place to go after a hangover.
Overall i have been there a few times, but i never find myself missing this place...
author: Jose A. P.

description: We ate brunch at Olympic because the line for Dottie's was about an hour.  What drew me in was the blue sign outside that said, "Pancakes, Waffles". There was no wait to get seated and they seemed to have an extensive menu and lots of specials. I ended up getting the waffles with fruit. The fruit being a banana. The waffle was soggy and slopped with butter. I asked for a refill for my coffee and it took the waitress about 10 minutes and she only filled it up half way! I definitely regretted not staying in line for Dottie's, this place blew big time.
author: Debbie C.

description: Not as bad as some of the reviews suggested. Buckwheat pancakes were solid, coffee a little weak. Service was average.
author: Garrett B.

description: Had breakfast here as had friends visiting and they were staying at the Adagio Hotel right across the street. I ordered the spinach, mushroom and cheese omelette and it was really good. In fact, my friends were pissed they didn't order that themselves. One had the corned beef hash (which was pretty good too, but there were some large chunks of potatoes which was weird) and the other had the pattie with eggs. All in all, not a bad breakfast, but service was extremely slow because there were only 2 people taking orders/serving and the place was packed! However, to give them credit, we stayed for a long time chatting and they didn't shoo us away or anything, but left us alone. That is a big plus!
author: Anita L.

description:
I'm suprised yelp isn't eating this place up (sorry, bad pun) BUT, this place is grrrrreat (sorry I love frosted flakes).

I choose to travel from nob hill to the "hotel district" (geary and taylor), most Sundays to eat at this joint.  C'mon kids, its a breakfast spot, relax a little bit.  It gets busy and you have to ask for coffee and more cream, but the gal will do it if your nice; show a little sympathy, enjoy your Mimosa.

The food is spectacular!  I'm a big advocate for tapatio and st/ppr, but I've enjoyed their homefries bareback and they are delish!!

Many different omelets to choose from, the food is Good.  I'm happy nobody has bagged on that. I get a new and different omelet 50% of the time. Very comfortable seating too, even the bar is nice.
