This place has great food, with practically unlimited variety, amazing olympic cafe specials (the san francisco), comfortable seating, always find a seat, servers give their all, very reasonable pricing, and DELICIOUS grub.  

Man, 5 of 5, this is my bfast spot; have fun at Mel's if you don't want the above
author: Brandon E.

description: Very good value - check out the Northwestern scramble.
author: Paul C.

description: I like this place, but there is nothing spectacular about it.  My Denver omelette was totally acceptable, but not really noteworthy.  The coffee was slightly burned from sitting on the warmer too long, and the butter was still frozen.  Complaints aside, I immediately got a table and the service was fine.  There are lots of small two-person booths, which is nice if you want to linger for a while without feeling guilty about monopolizing a big table.  Beware: CASH ONLY.
author: Victor H.

description: We came upon this breakfast place after deciding the line at Dotties True Blue Cafe was far too long.  Though a little on the rough looking side, this place served up a very tasty breakfast.  We opted for the whole grain pancakes with blueberries and bananas and I don't think they charged us any extra for the fruit.
author: Ashley F.

description: This is my favorite breakfast place!! The first time I came here I ordered biscuits and gravy...if you are cold or kinda tired and grumpy, this will change that! Best comfort food, great omlettes and perfect French toast. Hearty greasy food!!
author: Kat R.

description:
I was recently on a quest for chicken fried steak. I'm from the south, so outside of it, folks call it "country fried steak." Nonetheless, I walked ALL around the Lower Nob Hill/Union Square/Tenderloin area looking for it, and only Lori's had it...for $15. 

Fuck that. 

We're talking about a dish that involves a breaded and fried cube steak and some flour gravy with the grease from the steak. NOT a $15 dish. 

The Olympic had it, but it was on their breakfast menu; I was looking for a lunch. They gladly prepared the dish with the lunch sides...and although it wasn't quite as good as what I used to find in the South, it was still (a) good (b) cheap and (c) served with a smile. Right on, Olympic!
author: Derek R.

description: The expected mediocre food came quickly and not at the same time. Started off just that until we heard some scrapping at the next booth and see a terrified couple leaving immediately after noticing a bug.
author: Nick V.

description: I had a great breakfast at this diner. My bf and I wanted to try Dotties but with the line down the block it hardly seemed worth the wait so we walked around the corner and saw this diner where we sat right away. I had an avocado bacon and cheese omelette and he had the banana pancakes and both were delicious. Their country fries were really good, usually its dripping in grease but these were barely greased. I can't imagine another breakfast place being exponentially better to be worth the wait.
author: Janie W.

description: The food was so quick. Quickest ever. Classic breakfast spot styling. A place where you could see Roger and Dee taking Mama for a birthday brunch on the show What's Happening. Pancakes are good. Scrambled eggs coulda been better. The young foreign waitress was an added attractive bonus. Sit at the counter.
author: Tim O.

description:
After some walking, my friends and I settled on this "cafe". 
I pointed out they had a people love us on yelp sticker. I mean who? 19 reviews and counting and most people are rating what i'm rating.

The place has a very ugly diner ambiance. Torn seat cushions, dirty walls. The cooks kinda stared over at our tables as if we were convicts. 
I settled on the grilled tomato, avocado and cheese sandwich plus a side of french toast. The sandwich was ok. It would have been better if my toast wasn't so burnt. My friend noted how burnt his toast was also. The sandwich also comes with fries that look fresh cut but are not cooked all the way, it was soggy also. The only highlight had to be the french toast that went down well which is why they recieve one star.
All in all, would not come back again.
author: Lily N.

description:
Famous for omeletes. Good breakfast place in union square.
Not that calm and nice but I guess it's good when you feel starving in the morning.
author: Woosung A.

description: The "omelet" was really just scrambled eggs with fixins' mixed in. Staff was nice but overworked.
author: Brian C.

description:
i don't get the negativity on this place...

it' my previous neighborhood greasy plate diner place and i loved every GD bite.

even if the twin sisters from eastern europe got pissed at me every time i ordered a friedegg on my grilled ham n cheese..

get extra bkfst potatoes!
author: G G.

description:
Went there twice.  The buckwheat pancakes were the culprit.

We had a veggie omelete, a breakfast burrito and buckwheat pancakes.

The omelete was pretty good.  The eggs were cooked well.  The burrito was ok, nothing special.

The buckwheat pancakes were really good.  I could easily eat 2 orders of those.  They are slightly smaller than standard size pancakes, and there are 3 of them, but they don't stuff you as much as the regular pancakes.

The first time we went there, the service was pretty bad and the check came out $10 over what it was supposed to be, but the waitress fixed it.

The second time we went there, the waitress was a lot nicer and the service seemed much better.

I'd go there for the pancakes again and the veggie omelet if I was in the area.
author: Misha M.

description: Breakfast is not delicious, but I don't have the time to wait at Dottie's every day.  Egg white only option a plus, especially at a greasy diner!
author: Wakako U.

description:
Worst service I've ever experienced in the US. To say the waitress was rude would be a massive understatement; let's just say the service industry isn't the right career choice for her. After seeing the colourful and inviting 'BREAKFAST' sign we sat at a booth here and waited for the waitress to take our order. And waited. After about 15 minutes of reaching a higher state of hungriness, we asked the waitress if we could order and she snapped "I'll take your order when I'M ready." 

You think this would be enough of an indication that this is a place where you don't want to stick around, but before we had too much time to think about it she was back to actually take our order and pour some coffees. Then, my friend made the mistake of asking of we could get the table cleaned as there were chunks of meat still lying around left behind from the previous booth occupant (so it looks like someone did get breakfast here at some point). What happened next was unexpected and extremely unpleasant if somewhat amusing: the waitress freaked out. Freaked. Out. "Why did you sit at a dirty table? It's your problem!!" She stomped off and proceeded to badmouth us within earshot to every other table, because we'd had the audacity and downright stupidity to sit at a dirty table. Shocker, apparently we'd broken the code of greasy spoon conduct.

The experience was vaguely ok up until this point, as in I would probably still have seen it through and eaten here. But the waitress then refilled everyone other table at the diner with coffee while blanking us. Eventually her war-weary henpecked colleague came over to attempt to clean our table before asking us exasperatedly: "How can I clean the table with you all sitting here?" Uhm. Apparently the science of table cleaning is a highly skilled and complex field which we completely underestimated. So we left. 

Which means I unfortunately can't review the food, but honestly, I really wouldn't bother unless masochism is your thing.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Nothing special about the place.  Saw it in the bay city guide and decided to try it out since it was down the street from our hotel.  Got the meat omlette and french toast.  The omlette was slightly overcooked but it didn't taste too bad.  I'm sure there are much better places around but it's not bad for a quick breakfast.
author: Katie V.

description: I'll admit, I was starving when I came here..so my review may be a bit skewed.  Pretty much anything is good when you're starving right? Overall, Olympic Cafe is your typical diner with solid breakfast foods. We ordered the French Toast special w/ bananas and their Hash Brown special plus 2 coffees. Portions were large and the food came quick! Solid 3 stars and I'd come back here if I was back in the TL.
author: Allene J.

description: Place looks a little dumpy but the staff is friendly. Food was good. A typical greasy spoon.
author: Mike B.

description: Diner food at it's best!  I had a great time starting my new year off at the Olympic Flame Cafe!  I had the biscuits and gravy with home fries, which was so tasty and filling.  My friends all got egg dishes which they said were pleasing.  The service was not that amazing but the setting makes up for that.  It's so cute inside, classic, vintage airport diner.  It feels like it should be in Reno, the rose pink booths, the bald eagle and ocean wave photos that reside on the walls, it's all fits too perfectly together in a mismatched way.  And it's cheap, cheap, cheap!!!
author: Steven K.

description: It's a greasy spoon, guys. Whaddyaexpect? If you're into this sort of thing, you'll like this place. I give it a solid OK - with extra credit for scaring away all the Foodies.
author: Ronald M.

description: When you are too hungry to wait in line at Dottie's, go around the corner and eat the buckwheat pancakes or the 'window' omelette with avocado, spinach and cheddar cheese. Huge plates of food.  I always sit at the counter, as the wait staff is not so fast on their feet. Also, the orange juice is not freshly squeezed, as advertised. Their coffee is for old people: thin and flavorless. Small matter, once the food arrives its all good. MMMMMMMmmmmmmmmmmmmm, yum!
author: Heather G.

description: If I could give zero stars, I would. I used to eat here when I first moved to the neighborhood eight years ago. I haven't eaten there in ages. I now remember why. The food is bad and the service is worse. My eggs were under cooked. God, how I hate runny egg whites--it looks like snot. The oatmeal my mom ordered looked and tasted like vomit. I couldn't get the server's attention, so I had to get up and walk over to her. When I mentioned the issues with our food, the server rolled her eyes and shrugged her shoulders. Oh, and BTW, I did not describe the food as snot or vomit when I complained--I said the eggs were undercooked and the oatmeal was overcooked. She wasn't much in the mood for coming up with solutions, so we left. I hope I don't have another memory lapse and find myself attempting to eat there five years from now.
author: Wendy G.

description: One of the nastiest breakfasts I've ever had. The server was rude and basically kept ignoring me every time I tried to get their attention. The food itself was almost inedible. The eggs were greasy and had chunks of other food from the grill in it. Avoid this dump
author: John T.

description:
only go here if you are desperate and don't expect anything but huffing and grunting from the rough talking russian wait staff and a glassy-eyed look of indifference from the over-worked cook . Expect the most basic of the diner breakfast experience and your stomach will remind you that you just ingested copious amounts of fat and oil no matter what it was that you ate. 

You get the feeling that this is the sort of place that hasn't been expected by health officials since Willie Brown was around
author: Dylan M.

description:
a classic diner with questionable counter and table "service," but offering positively delectable breakfast food!

came into this place on new years' day... and the waitresses looked like sisters. too bad neither one of them knows how to wait on tables. they did one thing on the floor... then back to the kitchen.. piecemeal service.

BUT!! The food came out and we were in heaven. super crispy and juicy home fries and a hollandaise bursting with lemon overtones that matched perfectly with the yolks. yummy! I will certainly go back....

SF, please quit with your over-hyped nook restaurants. please. just get over it.
author: Jason s.

description: Run of the mill greasy spoon diner open for breakfast and lunch.  The best part is that you will be transported to 1970's small town America. . . or at least an alternative San Francisco version where they had already discovered feta cheese, non-iceberg lettuce, and ethnic sausages.  My roommate is a chef and she endorses the place.
author: Gil S.

description: I like their omelets; the tables are small and run-down, and service can get a little slow.  But it's a good place to go nurse a hangover at 11:30AM when you're not ready to admit breakfast time is long past.  which is what i was doing both times I went.
author: Cassio P.

description:
Utterly terrible.  So we were going to go to Dottie's, and came here because there was a line.  We sit down, and are basically ignored for like 15 minutes.  The waitress finally comes to us with a grim look on her face and belts out "Are you ready?".  Nope, we weren't because she hadnt even brought us menus.  So she basically throws the menus at us, and walks of muttering something in another language.  We got our food pretty fast, but it was bad.  I felt ripped off with my 'country breakfast' which I could have gotten at denny's for a couple bucks cheaper and would have come with hashbrowns and an extra pancake.  My 'cappuccino' was of the instant carnation variety, and there was a strange taste to the sausage. My girlfriend's 'chicken apple sausage omelette tasted more like spam and hardly had any cheese.  Her toast was a nice grocery store mass produced variety, and her coffee was grey.  $22 for a non-filling super crappy breakfast.  Bad food, bad service, stupid prices for breakfast stuff when the portions aren't even big.  Avoid this place, you're better off going down the block to burger king or jack in the box.  Wish i could give a 0 star rating.  You guys rating this place above a 2 need to stop hanging out with the tenderloin locals, I think it's affecting your judgement.

**UPDATE** due to waking up with 'stomach problems' this morning very early from this meal, I'm taking off another star, bringing the rating to -1
author: Brett T.

description: Seriously, get the chicken fried steak! The potatoes are also killer, for once somebody thought to season them.....
author: jake k.

description: I've been here before and it's been ok. Decent greasy spoon. But on a recent visit my egg scramble with smoked salmon, cream cheese and green onions came with a rubber band in it. That's pretty much a deal breaker. They replaced it with a gruff apology, but still charged me. Hope they enjoy the $12.
author: ros k.

description: As the below reviews state, the Olympic is nothing more than a typical American diner.  Their omelettes are above average, but that's pretty much all that's better than mediocre.  Their waffles aren't Belgian but are more like out of the box Eggos....I went when I discovered the line at Dottie's was too long, but I went to Dottie's the next day.  If you're not looking for a really special meal, the Olympic is okay...
author: Zach S.

description:
I'm surprised by some of these negative reviews. I am particularly surprised by the ones who mention poor service or rude staff. I don't know if I was lucky with the timing or if you guys were just unlucky but the waitress we had was very sweet and took care of us as soon as we sat down.

We had breakfast and it was pretty much perfect diner food. It is supposed to be greasy, folks. It can't all be avocados and bean sprouts. It was exactly what I wanted and I will definitely make a return visit next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: jason b.

description: I love this place. It's not fancy. It's not perfect. But I love coming here every few weeks because I like the sweet people who work here and the simple but hot and tasty breakfasts they serve. My favorite is their Joe's Special Scramble because they put way more spinach in it than most places and it turns out great. I just had that today. But I've had lots of other breakfasts at Olympic and I like them, too. "Two eggs with Italian sausage" is also really, really good. I also think their biscuits and gravy are pretty good. Oh and this is funky: eating here was the first time I was ever served a double-yolked egg. That blew my mind.
author: Tim N.

description:
Yummmmy....this is the best diner in SF. The staff is friendly and efficient, and there is a particular staff member that is a hottie (check him out Sunday mornings) :-) 

The biscuits and gravy are great, as well as the chicken-apple sausage! Shopping and satisfying food all in one day! What more could a girl want?
author: Ann S.

description: i went there once for breakfast and i actually experience a good time. i ordered the brk. quesadilla and it was the best! my bf had a denver omelet aND I guess he liked it since he ate the whole thing... hahaha i will defenately go back and try there other options!
author: Silvia C.

description: Olympic Cafe is what it is: A hole in the wall greasy spoon diner that provides a solid breakfast with large portions and varied menu. I Sat at the counter with the fam and got great, fast, honest service ("you don't want the spinach, it's frozen" said the waitress in a Romanian accent). I'll return again for that big fat breakfast.
author: Bret A.

description:
"are you going to be paying for that coffee-refill? i've already done it twice"

enough said. i am never going back to this crappy place (food, service, "ambience") again.
author: k w.

description: ok so i've had some good hung over, wanting to get crunk again immediately type breakfast/brunches here and it's usually a damn good spot. in fact, when we were thinking of spots to head to, i was all stoked that this was the place. but it's ghetto appeal manifested itself today as straight ghetto, lack of appeal, please don't give me some botulism but im down with some pretty raw meat kinda thing....so i order up the chicken fried steak, an old southern fav grease attack, but ghetto enough that the peeps selling it on the west coast get it from the same government cheese-making distributor that they do back there, so it's a cool or whatever kinda thing. and my other friend changes his mind cuz that sounds too good not to go for, and then my other friend comes this close to changing his too, then sticks with the burger. nothing fancy, just a burger. so it comes out looking all dope, super stank and greasy, just like we like em, but then the dude starts eating it and makes a face. next thing i know he's like dude this is the rawness, like no good style, abort, abort... so we flag the waitress who seemed cool enough, and when he shows her she's immediately all about how raw it is and blah blah whatever and goes to fix. well im sure they're just gonna cook a new burger, cuz this one was covered in mayo, , lettuce, tomato, chesse, etc, all the all-the-way stuff, and it's only a burger right, no filets around here.... so i see the waitress dealing with it for several minutes but cant tell exactly what up, then in a few, dude gets the whole plate back, same plate, and the thing is freaking viciously hot and the the burger is like a soggy, microwaved out, whole thing, lettuce and all, funky ish monster, just chillin with some home fries, looking sad and busted. so when they under cook some ground beef around here, basically it's like a commodity that can't be wasted in any way, and it's funny cuz i was like assuring my friend that they would just cut their losses and bust out a new one after the initial screw up...but no, not really....so even tho my chicken fried steaks was dope, and the joe's special rocks, i mean everything else was generally the chronic, this one time really sketched me out and needs documenting...basically i just learned to tell the peeps, 'make me a new one' and not leave it up to them to fix some busted burger, i mean yelp dis what up......word to the wise
author: billy m.
